text.p: The Pentagon may recommend divestiture to curb any anti-competitive impact on the defense industry of the Boeing Co's proposed merger with McDonnell Douglas Corp or could halt the deal altogether, Defense Secretary William Perry said on Saturday.
In a taped interview on the CNN program "Evans and Novak," Perry said a Defense Department review of the combination began shortly after the companies announced their plan last weekend.

"The issue is whether one segment of the defense industry is monopolized as a result of it," he said. "And if it is, we can either recommend stopping the merger or we can recommend divestiture of the one segment which is likely to be a problem."

"That might happen," he added, in response to a question. "It has happened in the past. It could happen this time." But Perry gave no indication that the Pentagon would seek any such action. President Clinton has nominated Sen. William Cohen, a Maine Republican, to replace Perry as defense secretary.
Boeing President Phil Condit told reporters last Sunday the new combined company would continue selling Douglas planes as long as there was a market for them.
